description: Fixed version with minimal changes to address the vulnerability
root_cause:
Single developer had access to admin private keys without multi-sig or oversight, allowing malicious upgrades

Key Weaknesses: Single developer with critical key access; No multi-signature requirement; Missing timelock delay
attack_scenario:
Rogue developer upgrades LockManager, modifies user withdrawal addresses, drains all locked funds

Attack Flow: Rogue developer (DPRK operative) hired by project with admin access → Developer prepares malicious LockManager implementation → Uses admin key to upgrade contract without review → For each user: setLockRecipient(user, attackerWallet) → Calls emergencyUnlock() for all users → Funds flow to attacker's controlled addresses ($62M total) → Transfers to external wallets for mixing → Project traces identity, discovers DPRK link → Negotiations result in full fund return (unusual outcome) → All users compensated, project continues operations
fix_description: Require multi-signature (3-of-5) for all admin actions; Implement timelock delay (48 hours) for upgrades; Only users can change their own withdrawal addresses
